poem:
Cycle of Knowing  

Once a month, dreams  
wane, dissolve in sighs—  
her quiet question, the rhythm  
unseen but intimate—  
not a moon's orbit, nor a  
mystic's murmur,  
but the clockwork pulse  
of being, whispering,  
"Here, here."  

So I rise, breathe,  
and measure the growing light  
in another cycle.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Cycle tracking isn’t woo-woo or a tradwife tool. It’s essential education for everyone – no matter the gender | Freya Bennett Once a month without fail I decide to give up on all my goals and ambitions. “There’s just no point,” I sigh to my mother, who smiles and asks what day of my cycle I’m on. I grumble back, insisting it has nothing to do with my period, I just happen to have lost". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Cycle tracking isn’t woo-woo or a tradwife tool.
